issues.title: Interpolating an invalid reference include confusing error
issues.author: timotheeguerin
issues.reproCode: const b = "Some ${bad}";
issues.compilerOutput:
TypeSpec compiler v1.9.0

Diagnostics were reported during compilation:

main.tsp:1:19 - error invalid-ref: Unknown identifier bad
> 1 | const b = "Some ${bad}";
    |                   ^^^
main.tsp:1:19 - error non-literal-string-template: Value interpolated in this string template cannot be converted to a string. Only literal types can be automatically interpolated.
> 1 | const b = "Some ${bad}";
    |                   ^^^

Found 2 errors.
issues.suggestedAction: Bug confirmed ‚Äî still reproduces with latest compiler.
issues.reproDescription:
When interpolating an invalid reference in a string template, the compiler reports two errors:

1. `invalid-ref: Unknown identifier bad` - This is correct, as `bad` is not defined
2. `non-literal-string-template: Value interpolated in this string template cannot be converted to a string` - This is confusing and redundant

The issue is that the `non-literal-string-template` error should not be reported when the interpolated value is already an error type. This second error message is confusing because it's not the real problem - the real problem is that `bad` is undefined.

Expected: Only the `invalid-ref` error should be reported.
Actual: Both errors are reported, making the error message confusing.

actions.label: Add compiler:core
actions.command: gh issue edit 9606 --add-label "compiler:core" --remove-label needs-area --repo microsoft/typespec

issues.title: [Bug]: Emitted Python code with bullet-list in doc string results in Sphinx error
issues.author: dargilco
issues.suggestedAction: Bug confirmed ‚Äî still reproduces with latest compiler.
issues.reproDescription:
## Issue Description

The `@typespec/http-client-python` emitter generates Python docstrings with invalid reStructuredText formatting when the source TypeSpec includes doc comments with bullet lists.

### Observed Behavior

When a TypeSpec model property is documented with a comment containing bullet-list items (starting with `-`), the emitter produces Python code like:

```python
:ivar output: An array of content items generated by the model.

 * The length and order of items in the `output` array is dependent
 on the model's response.
 * Rather than accessing the first item in the `output` array and
 assuming it's an `assistant` message with the content generated by
 the model, you might consider using the `output_text` property where
 supported in SDKs. Required.
:vartype output: list[~azure.ai.projects.models.OutputItem]
```

Notice the **blank line before the bullet list** (between "the model." and the `*` bullet point).

### Expected Behavior

The emitter should not insert a blank line between the summary and the bullet list in reStructuredText docstrings. The correct format should be:

```python
:ivar output: An array of content items generated by the model.
 * The length and order of items in the `output` array is dependent
 ...
```

### Impact

When this generated Python code is processed by Sphinx (a documentation generator), it produces the error:

```
WARNING: Bullet list ends without a blank line; unexpected unindent. [docutils]
```

Removing the blank line before the bullet list manually fixes the Sphinx error, confirming that the issue is in the emitter's docstring formatting logic.

### Root Cause

The Python client emitter appears to be inserting a blank line when transitioning from a paragraph to a bullet list in the docstring, which violates reStructuredText's formatting rules.

issues.title: application/xml bytes treated as binary payload
issues.author: timotheeguerin
issues.compilerOutput:
TypeSpec compiler v1.9.0


Compilation completed successfully.
issues.suggestedAction: Bug confirmed ‚Äî still reproduces with latest compiler.
issues.reproDescription:
## Issue Summary

When using `bytes` type for a response body in TypeSpec with the OpenAPI3 emitter, the generated OpenAPI spec uses `application/octet-stream` as the content-type instead of allowing the user to specify other content types like `application/xml`.

## Expected Behavior

Users should be able to specify that bytes content should be serialized/treated as XML (or any other content type) in the OpenAPI output.

## Actual Behavior

The OpenAPI3 emitter generates:
```yaml
responses:
  '200':
    description: The request has succeeded.
    content:
      application/octet-stream:
        schema:
          type: string
          format: binary
```

Instead of:
```yaml
responses:
  '200':
    description: The request has succeeded.
    content:
      application/xml:
        schema:
          type: string
          format: binary
```

## Root Cause

The `bytes` type always defaults to `application/octet-stream` content-type in OpenAPI output. While TypeSpec has a `File` type that can specify custom content types, there is no clean way to use `bytes` with a custom content type like XML.

## Note

The issue also mentions that typespec-autorest has the same bug. A comment suggests adding a warning when a spec uses this pattern if it cannot be easily fixed.

issues.title: additional `items` section for properties with array type but array encoding
issues.author: iscai-msft
issues.compilerOutput:
TypeSpec compiler v1.9.0


Compilation completed successfully.
issues.suggestedAction: Bug confirmed ‚Äî still reproduces with latest compiler.
issues.reproDescription:
## Issue: Incorrect `items` field in OpenAPI3 schema with array encoding

### What the bug is about
When a TypeSpec model property is an array type with array encoding decorator (e.g., `@encode(ArrayEncoding.commaDelimited)`), the OpenAPI3 emitter incorrectly includes both an `items` field and a `format` field in the generated schema.

### Expected behavior
When array encoding is applied, the array should be serialized as a scalar value (comma-delimited string) in the OpenAPI schema. The `items` field should NOT be present because the property is no longer represented as a traditional OpenAPI array.

### Actual behavior (bug observed)
The generated OpenAPI3 schema incorrectly includes:
```yaml
prop:
  type: string
  items:
    type: string
  format: ArrayEncoding.commaDelimited
```

The `items` field should not be present when array encoding is specified. The property should be:
```yaml
prop:
  type: string
  format: ArrayEncoding.commaDelimited
```

### Verification
Compiled with @typespec/openapi3 emitter (v1.9.0). The bug is confirmed in the generated openapi.yaml output.

### Related information
A similar fix was made in the Azure autorest emitter: https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/pull/3666

issues.title: [Bug]: tsp-openapi generates invalid tagMetadata objects
issues.author: sensiblewood-ozone
issues.reproCode:
openapi: 3.0.0
info:
  title: Test API
  version: 1.0.0
paths:
  /consents:
    get:
      tags:
        - consents
      summary: Get consents
      responses:
        '200':
          description: Success
tags:
  - name: consents
issues.compilerOutput: The generated TypeSpec code contains: @tagMetadata("consents") with only 1 argument, but the decorator requires 2 arguments.
issues.suggestedAction: Bug confirmed ‚Äî still reproduces with latest compiler.
issues.reproDescription:
# Reproduction Details

The tsp-openapi3 converter generates invalid TypeSpec code when converting OpenAPI 3.0 tags that have no description.

## Reproduction Steps
1. Create an OpenAPI 3.0 document with a tag that has no description (only the `name` field)
2. Run `tsp-openapi3 convert` to convert the OpenAPI file to TypeSpec

## Expected Behavior
The converter should generate:
```typespec
@tagMetadata("consents", #{})
```
This provides both required arguments to the decorator.

## Actual Behavior
The converter generates:
```typespec
@tagMetadata("consents")
```
This provides only 1 argument, which causes a compiler error: `Expected 2 arguments, but got 1.`

## Root Cause
In the `generate-tags.js` file of @typespec/openapi3, when both `description` and `externalDocs` are empty, the `tagMetadata` variable becomes an empty string. The decorator is then generated as `@tagMetadata("${tag.name}"${tagMetadata})` which results in only 1 argument.

## Fix
When `tagMetadata` is empty, it should default to `, #{}` instead of an empty string, ensuring the decorator always has 2 arguments.

actions.label: Add openapi3
actions.command: gh issue edit 9147 --add-label "openapi3" --repo microsoft/typespec

issues.title: [Bug]: [http-server-csharp] model that extends another model with no additional properties are not emitted as C# class
issues.author: k117117117
issues.compilerOutput:
TypeSpec compiler v1.9.0


Compilation completed successfully.
issues.suggestedAction: Bug confirmed ‚Äî still reproduces with latest compiler.
issues.reproDescription:
The @typespec/http-server-csharp emitter fails to generate a C# class file for model `Baz` which extends `Foo` without adding any additional properties.

**Expected behavior**: Model `Baz` should be emitted as `generated/models/Baz.cs` as a C# class that inherits from `Foo`, similar to how `Bar` is emitted.

**Actual behavior**: Only `Foo.cs` and `Bar.cs` are generated in `generated/models/`, but `Baz.cs` is missing.

**Generated files**:
- ‚úì `generated/models/Foo.cs` - public partial class Foo with id and name properties
- ‚úì `generated/models/Bar.cs` - public partial class Bar : Foo with code property
- ‚úó `generated/models/Baz.cs` - NOT GENERATED (this is the bug)

The issue reporter wants `Baz.cs` to be generated so they can add handwritten code in a partial class. This is a valid use case for extending a model without adding properties.

issues.title: [Bug]: MergePatchUpdate graph representation not ideal
issues.author: bterlson
issues.suggestedAction: Could not verify ‚Äî needs manual review.
issues.reproDescription:
This issue describes an internal problem with how the TypeSpec compiler represents the `MergePatchUpdate` graph node when processing PATCH operations in the HTTP library.

**The Problem:**
- When the compiler creates a graph for PATCH operations, the body of the operation references a `MergePatchUpdate` template node
- However, the properties of this template node reference the actual mutated model with the correct name
- This inconsistency causes emitters to receive conflicting information: the body node references `MergePatchUpdate` while its properties point to the real model
- Emitters must apply `friendlyName` carefully and avoid generating duplicate types when they encounter both the `MergePatchUpdate` template and the actual mutated model in the graph

**Root Cause:**
The issue appears to be caused by using a decorator-based approach to mutate the model properties during template expansion, rather than having a first-class template function mechanism.

**Emitter Impact:**
Emitters that process PATCH operations need workarounds:
- Apply `friendlyName` to handle the `MergePatchUpdate` reference correctly
- Normalize the `MergePatchUpdate` graph node to the first property's `.model` to avoid duplicate type definitions
- Be careful not to emit the same model twice in different forms

**Note:** This cannot be directly verified through compilation testing, as the code compiles successfully. The issue is about the internal graph structure representation that emitters must interpret. A fix would require changes to how the compiler builds the graph for merge-patch templates, possibly by replacing the decorator-based model mutation with a template function approach.

issues.title: [Bug]: MergePatchUpdate behaves badly with subsequent mutations
issues.author: bterlson
issues.suggestedAction: Missing reproduction. Needs repro from reporter.
issues.reproDescription: This is a compiler internal API bug. The issue describes a problem with how `$applyMergePatch` handles model properties during mutation. When a model is cloned with `$.type.clone()` after being processed with `$.type.finishType()` following a merge patch operation, the cloned model incorrectly shares the same properties object as the original (i.e., `clone.properties === original.properties` evaluates to true). This violates the invariant that clones should have fresh/independent properties. This bug is in the compiler's internal type system API and cannot be reproduced through TypeSpec language code alone ‚Äî it requires direct API access to `$applyMergePatch`, `$.type.clone()`, and `$.type.finishType()`.

issues.title: Werid formatting on augment decorator/op
issues.author: timotheeguerin
issues.suggestedAction: Could not verify ‚Äî needs manual review.
issues.reproDescription:
The issue shows two TypeSpec code examples with unusual line break formatting:

1. A multi-line operation decorator where the opening parenthesis of the parameter list breaks to a new line with only the closing parenthesis.
2. An augment decorator with a very long namespace path that breaks awkwardly across lines.

The issue appears to be about how the TypeSpec formatter or IDE displays code with long decorator names and operation parameter lists. The title mentions 'formatting' which suggests this may be related to how code is pretty-printed or displayed in the IDE/playground rather than a compilation error.

issues.title: tspd: gen-extern-signatures is broken for subpath exports
issues.author: witemple-msft
issues.suggestedAction: Could not verify ‚Äî needs manual review.
issues.reproDescription: This is a design/implementation issue in the TSPD tool itself, not a TypeSpec language bug with a code reproduction. The issue describes that TSPD's `gen-extern-signatures` feature is broken for subpath exports because TSPD lacks the ability to track where decorators are lexically defined in the source code. The problems are: (1) TSPD always treats `$decorators` as if exported from the root package, even for subpath-defined decorators; (2) If decorators are in the root `$decorators`, the library linter complains about missing `extern dec` declarations; (3) If decorators are in subpath `$decorators` (correct structure), TSPD cannot generate correct test files because it doesn't know which subpath maps to a decorator. The solution proposed is to disable signature generation for subpaths until this architectural issue is resolved.

actions.label: Request repro
actions.command: gh issue comment 8913 --repo microsoft/typespec --body "Thanks for filing this issue! Could you provide a minimal reproduction? You can use the [TypeSpec Playground](https://typespec.io/playground) to create one and share the link. This helps us investigate and fix the issue faster."

issues.title: [Bug]: @typespec/openapi3 Nullable union expression generates invalid openapi3
issues.author: glecaros
issues.compilerOutput:
TypeSpec compiler v1.9.0


Compilation completed successfully.
issues.suggestedAction: Bug confirmed ‚Äî still reproduces with latest compiler.
issues.reproDescription:
## Issue Description
When a model property has a union type that includes `null` (e.g., `string | int32 | null`), the @typespec/openapi3 emitter generates invalid OpenAPI 3.0 schema.

## Expected Behavior
According to the OpenAPI 3.0 specification, the `nullable` keyword should only be used in conjunction with an explicit `type` field. When using `anyOf` to represent a union of multiple types, `nullable` should not be placed at the root level of the schema.

## Actual Behavior
The emitter generates:
```yaml
bar:
  anyOf:
    - type: string
    - type: integer
      format: int32
  nullable: true
```

This is invalid according to the OpenAPI 3.0 specification. The `nullable: true` at the root level (alongside `anyOf`) violates the spec validation rules.

## Discussion
Comments in the issue suggest that:
1. In OpenAPI 3.0, this should be represented by putting `nullable: true` on each variant within the `anyOf` array instead
2. OpenAPI 3.1 handles this more naturally

## Suggestion
The emitter should either:
- Move `nullable: true` to each variant in the `anyOf` array, or
- Emit a warning that this pattern cannot be properly represented in OpenAPI 3.0 and omit the `nullable` property

issues.title: Importing package that make use of stdout crash language server
issues.author: timotheeguerin
issues.reproCode: import "@autorest/openapi-to-typespec";
issues.compilerOutput:
TypeSpec compiler v1.9.0


Compilation completed successfully.

No emitter was configured, no output was generated. Use `--emit <emitterName>` to pick emitter or specify it in the TypeSpec config.
issues.suggestedAction: Could not verify ‚Äî needs manual review.
issues.reproDescription:
This is an IDE-specific issue that cannot be fully verified through command-line compilation. The issue occurs when the TypeSpec language server attempts to load `@autorest/openapi-to-typespec` package. The package uses stdout during initialization, which interferes with the Language Server Protocol (LSP) communication that relies on stdout/stdin for message passing. This causes the language server to crash when the package is imported.

The reproduction code compiles successfully via the CLI, but the language server will crash in VS Code or other LSP-enabled editors due to stdout pollution during module initialization.

issues.title: [Bug]: Confusing and wrong documentation on `is` vs `extend`
issues.author: artsiommiksiuk
issues.suggestedAction: Documentation bug ‚Äî lower priority than code bugs.
issues.reproDescription:
This is a documentation bug, not a code bug. The issue reports that the TypeSpec documentation at https://typespec.io/docs/language-basics/models/#using-the-is-operator contains confusing and incorrect guidance on the `is` operator.

The main concerns raised:
1. The documentation recommends using `is Record<T>` instead of `extends`, but this recommendation is misleading because `is` and `extends` have different semantics
2. The `is` operator does not allow specifying new properties that are not of the base type, while `extends` does allow this
3. The documentation is missing important context that `is` transfers decorators while `extends` does not
4. When using `is` instead of `extends`, properties can be silently stripped out by the compiler without any errors

No TypeSpec code reproduction is applicable for this documentation issue. The issue needs to be addressed by updating the documentation to:
- Remove the recommendation to prefer `is` over `extends`
- Clarify the semantic differences between `is` and `extends`
- Explain that `is` transfers decorators while `extends` does not
- Provide clear guidance on when to use each operator

issues.title: [Bug]: Difficulty expressing optional type field for tool output submission across versions
issues.author: mike-taylor99
issues.suggestedAction: Could not verify ‚Äî needs manual review.
issues.reproDescription:
This issue is about expressing optional fields added in newer API versions within TypeSpec, specifically for the SubmitToolOutput operation in Azure REST API Specs. The challenge is that when adding an optional `type` field in a newer version:

1. Simply adding an optional field with `@added()` decorator changes the model signature for all versions
2. Using union types to discriminate between old (without type) and new (with type) formats is complex and doesn't cleanly isolate changes to newer versions only
3. The workaround used was to add the field to the shared type definition across all versions and document that it's optional, but this is not ideal for keeping specs version-safe

The issue is asking for a better pattern in TypeSpec to handle this scenario where:
- Old API versions don't include the field (truly absent)
- New API versions include the field (but still optional for backward compatibility)
- Generated SDK code doesn't break for old version clients

The basic repro compiles successfully, but represents a design question rather than a compiler bug. The issue is requesting guidance on better ways to express this pattern cleanly.

issues.author: AntonioVT

issues.suggestedAction: Bug confirmed ‚Äî still reproduces with latest compiler.
issues.reproDescription:
The @typespec/http-server-csharp emitter crashes when processing interface operations that use unresolved generic type parameters. The error occurs in the `#resolveOperationResponse` method when it encounters a `TemplateParameter` type that it doesn't know how to emit to C# code.

**Reproduction**: An interface with a generic operation like `get<T>(): T;` triggers the crash.

**Expected behavior**: The emitter should either (1) properly handle template parameters by resolving them, or (2) provide a helpful error message instead of crashing.

**Actual behavior**: The emitter crashes with "Encountered type TemplateParameter which we don't know how to emit."

issues.title: [Bug]: EmitterOptions defaults are not resolved.
issues.author: artsiommiksiuk
issues.suggestedAction: Could not verify ‚Äî needs manual review.
issues.reproDescription:
## Issue Summary

When defining EmitterOptions with JSON schema defaults in a custom TypeSpec emitter, the default values specified in the schema are not being applied to the `context.options` object passed to the `$onEmit` function.

## Expected Behavior

When an emitter defines EmitterOptions with JSON schema default values (e.g., `{ type: "string", nullable: true, default: null }`), those defaults should be merged into the `context.options` object at runtime. If a user does not provide a value for an option with a default, the default should be used.

## Actual Behavior

The `context.options` object receives an empty object `{}` instead of the schema defaults being applied. Even though the JSON schema specifies defaults, they are not being resolved and applied to the options object passed to the emitter.

## Why This Is a Problem

1. **Type Safety Issue**: The TypeScript interface shows that properties should have values (with defaults), but at runtime they are missing from the options object.
2. **Framework Inconsistency**: JSON schema defaults are standard JSON schema features and developers expect them to work as in other systems.
3. **Documentation Gap**: The schema is currently only used for IDE autocomplete, not for runtime validation or defaults substitution.

## Root Cause

The EmitterOptions defaults from the JSON schema are not being processed and applied to the options object before passing it to the `$onEmit` function.

## Verification

This issue requires manual review as it involves the emitter framework runtime behavior rather than TypeSpec compilation. A fix would need to be made in the TypeSpec compiler's emitter invocation logic to:
1. Parse the JSON schema for the emitter options
2. Extract default values
3. Merge those defaults into the options object
4. Pass the merged object to the `$onEmit` function

issues.title: [Bug]: @typespec/http-server-csharp generates JsonObject instead of dictionary types for Record<T> properties
issues.author: Tielem
issues.compilerOutput:
TypeSpec compiler v1.9.0


Compilation completed successfully.
issues.suggestedAction: Bug confirmed ‚Äî still reproduces with latest compiler.
issues.reproDescription:
## Bug Summary

The @typespec/http-server-csharp emitter generates `JsonObject` instead of strongly-typed `Dictionary<string, T>` or `IDictionary<string, T>` for `Record<T>` properties.

## Expected Behavior

When a TypeSpec model contains a `Record<T>` property, the generated C# code should produce a strongly-typed dictionary, e.g., `Dictionary<string, SimpleValue>`, maintaining type safety.

## Actual Behavior

The generated `ContainerWithRecord.cs` model contains:
```csharp
public JsonObject Items { get; set; }
```

Instead of the expected:
```csharp
public Dictionary<string, SimpleValue> Items { get; set; }
```

Using `JsonObject` causes a loss of type safety, making the Record property essentially useless from a type system perspective.

## Reproduction Verification

The reproduction compiles successfully and the C# code is generated. The bug is confirmed by inspecting the generated `generated/models/ContainerWithRecord.cs` file, which shows the property is indeed typed as `JsonObject` rather than `Dictionary<string, SimpleValue>`.

issues.title: [Bug]: Missing Namespace Imports in C# Code Generated from MergePatchUpdate<T> through http-server-csharp
issues.author: k117117117
issues.compilerOutput:
TypeSpec compiler v1.9.0

Compilation completed successfully.
issues.suggestedAction: Bug confirmed ‚Äî still reproduces with latest compiler.

issues.title: [Bug]: Duplicate extensions in OAS 3.1
issues.author: vijayasingam-paddle
issues.compilerOutput:
TypeSpec compiler v1.9.0

Compilation completed successfully.
issues.suggestedAction: Bug confirmed ‚Äî still reproduces with latest compiler.
issues.reproDescription:
## Bug Verification

The bug is confirmed and still reproduces with the latest TypeSpec compiler (v1.9.0).

### Reproduction Details

When using the `@extension` decorator on a query parameter in a TypeSpec model, the extension is duplicated in the generated OpenAPI 3.1.0 specification:

```yaml
components:
  parameters:
    QueryParams:
      name: id
      in: query
      required: true
      schema:
        type: string
        x-foo: bar      # Extension appears here (in schema)
      x-foo: bar        # Extension ALSO appears here (at parameter level)
      explode: false
```

### Expected Behavior

The extension should appear only at one level. According to OpenAPI 3.1.0 specification, extensions on parameters should be at the parameter level, not duplicated inside the schema object.

### Actual Behavior

The `@extension("x-foo", "bar")` decorator is being applied to both:
1. The parameter level (`x-foo: bar` at the QueryParams level)
2. The schema level (`x-foo: bar` inside the schema object)

This results in duplicate extension values in the generated OpenAPI specification.

issues.title: [Bug]: openapi3: ICE when using a custom scalar initializer as a default value
issues.author: willmtemple
issues.compilerOutput:
Emitter "@typespec/openapi3" crashed! This is a bug.
Please file an issue at https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/issues

TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'type')
    at serializeScalarValueAsJson (file:///.../dist/src/lib/examples.js:126:87)
issues.suggestedAction: Bug confirmed ‚Äî still reproduces with latest compiler.
issues.reproDescription:
The @typespec/openapi3 emitter crashes when encountering a model property with a custom scalar default value. Specifically, when a scalar type has an initializer function (like `init v4()`) and is used as a default value in a model property (like `id: uuid = uuid.v4()`), the emitter throws a TypeError: 'Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'type')' during the serialization of scalar values.

The issue is in the `serializeScalarValueAsJson` function which attempts to access the `.type` property of an undefined object when dealing with custom scalar initializers. The emitter should gracefully handle unknown scalar values by treating them as if they have a server-side default (the value is unknown to the OpenAPI spec generator).

issues.title: [Bug]: Visibility Classes do not inherit extension annotations.
issues.author: thegagne
issues.suggestedAction: Bug confirmed ‚Äî still reproduces with latest compiler.
issues.reproDescription:
## Bug Description

When a model is decorated with `@OpenAPI.extension()` (e.g., to apply AEP standards by adding `x-aep-resource`), models that inherit from it via visibility classes (created with the `@visibility` decorator) do not inherit the extension annotation.

## Expected Behavior

When a visibility class is created from a base model that has extension annotations, the generated OpenAPI schema for the visibility class should also include those extensions. This is important for AEP (API Improvement Proposals) compliance where resource schemas need specific extension metadata.

## Actual Behavior

The `Widget` model has the `@OpenAPI.extension("x-aep-resource", {...})` decorator applied to it. However, when visibility classes like `WidgetCreate` or `WidgetUpdate` are generated (via the `@visibility` decorator), these derived schemas do NOT include the `x-aep-resource` extension in the emitted OpenAPI output.

## Issue Details

The playground link demonstrates:
1. A base `Widget` model decorated with `@OpenAPI.extension("x-aep-resource", ...)`
2. Visibility-based schemas being generated from the base model
3. The generated OpenAPI spec showing that only the `Widget` schema has the extension, while `WidgetCreate` and `WidgetUpdate` do not

This breaks AEP compliance for visibility classes, as all resource-related schemas should carry the `x-aep-resource` extension.

issues.title: @example decorator not showing on a @path or @query components
issues.author: Devon-White
issues.compilerOutput:
TypeSpec compiler v1.9.0


Compilation completed successfully.
issues.suggestedAction: Bug confirmed ‚Äî still reproduces with latest compiler.
issues.reproDescription:
## Bug Confirmation

The `@example` decorator is not being included in the OpenAPI3 output for `@query` and `@path` parameters, although it works correctly for request body properties.

### Expected Behavior
When the `@example` decorator is applied to a parameter (whether `@query`, `@path`, or in the body), the generated OpenAPI3 schema should include the `example` field for all of them.

### Actual Behavior
- **Request body properties**: The `@example` decorator IS correctly rendered in the OpenAPI3 schema (e.g., `example: 2`)
- **Query parameters**: The `@example` decorator is NOT rendered (missing `example` field in the parameter definition)
- **Path parameters**: The `@example` decorator is NOT rendered (missing `example` field in the parameter definition)

### Generated OpenAPI3 Output Analysis

**Query parameter (missing example):**
```yaml
- name: query_test
  in: query
  required: true
  description: Query Test
  schema:
    type: integer
    format: int32
```

**Path parameter (missing example):**
```yaml
- name: path_test
  in: path
  required: true
  description: Path Test
  schema:
    type: integer
    format: int32
```

**Request body property (has example):**
```yaml
body_test:
  type: integer
  format: int32
  description: Body Test
  example: 2
```

The emitter needs to be updated to include the `example` field in the parameter schemas for query and path parameters, similar to how it handles request body properties.

issues.title: Wrongfully detected cycle drops properties
issues.author: timotheeguerin
issues.compilerOutput:
TypeSpec compiler v1.9.0

Compilation completed successfully.
issues.suggestedAction: Bug confirmed ‚Äî still reproduces with latest compiler.
issues.reproDescription:
## Bug Confirmation

The issue involves incorrect cycle detection in TypeSpec when spreading aliases that reference models with template parameters.

### What's happening:
When model `C` spreads `DefaultBaseParameters<{}>`, which contains `...Alias` (where `Alias = B`), the compiler incorrectly detects a cycle and marks the alias as an error type. This causes the spread to become a no-op, resulting in properties being dropped.

### Expected behavior:
Model `C` should successfully inherit properties from the spread:
- `DefaultBaseParameters<{}>` spreads `Alias`
- `Alias` is `B`
- Model `B` has property `prop: C`
- Therefore, `C` should have property `prop`

### Actual behavior:
The generated OpenAPI schema shows that model `C` is completely empty (no properties), confirming that the properties are wrongfully dropped:

```yaml
C:
  type: object
```

Should be:

```yaml
C:
  type: object
  properties:
    prop:
      $ref: '#/components/schemas/C'
```

This is a cycle detection issue in the compiler's `checkAlias` function that needs to be redesigned to properly handle template-based spreads as mentioned in the issue description.

issues.title: Validate model don't spread each other
issues.author: timotheeguerin
issues.compilerOutput:
TypeSpec compiler v1.9.0

- Compiling...
√ó Compiling...
Internal compiler error!
File issue at https://github.com/microsoft/typespec

Error: Unexpected pending resolutions found
  (Model) Foo => Bar
  (Model) Bar => Foo
issues.suggestedAction: Bug confirmed ‚Äî still reproduces with latest compiler.
issues.reproDescription: The issue demonstrates that circular model spread references cause an "Internal compiler error" with "Unexpected pending resolutions found". Models Foo and Bar both spread each other, creating a circular dependency that should be properly validated with a clear error message instead of causing an internal compiler error. The issue notes that fixing this with the current circular reference check gets too strict and breaks valid code like mutually-recursive aliases.

issues.title: Array declarations allow (but do not reflect) record spreads
issues.author: markcowl
issues.compilerOutput:
TypeSpec compiler v1.9.0

Compilation completed successfully.

No emitter was configured, no output was generated.
issues.suggestedAction: Bug confirmed ‚Äî still reproduces with latest compiler.
issues.reproDescription:
## Issue Summary

The TypeSpec compiler allows models with inconsistent indexers but does not warn the user or reflect the inconsistency in the compiled type graph.

## Reproduction

Two problematic patterns are demonstrated:

1. **Array with incompatible Record spread**: Model `Baz` is declared as `Array<int32>` (numeric indexing) but spreads `Record<string>` (string key indexing). This creates conflicting indexer semantics.

2. **Multiple incompatible Record spreads**: Model `Bar` spreads both `Record<string>` and `Record<int32>`, which have incompatible key types (string vs int32).

## Expected Behavior

The compiler should either:
- Reject these patterns with a clear error message, OR
- Warn the user about the inconsistent indexers and explain which indexer will be used

## Actual Behavior

The compiler silently accepts both patterns and compiles successfully without any diagnostic warnings. The type graph viewer in the playground then shows ambiguous or inconsistent behavior when these models are referenced.

## Impact

This can lead to confusion about the actual shape of these models at runtime, as the indexer semantics are unclear.

issues.title: [Bug]: Discriminated Types not supported by JSON emitter
issues.author: lukany
issues.compilerOutput:
TypeSpec compiler v1.9.0

Compilation completed successfully.
issues.suggestedAction: Bug confirmed ‚Äî still reproduces with latest compiler.
issues.reproDescription:
## Bug: Discriminated Types Missing Discriminator in JSON Schema

The TypeSpec `@discriminated` decorator is not properly supported by the JSON schema emitter. When a union is marked with `@discriminated`, the generated JSON schema should include a `discriminator` field that indicates which property is used to distinguish between union variants.

### Expected Behavior
According to the TypeSpec documentation on discriminated types, the generated JSON schema for a discriminated union should include discriminator metadata that identifies the discriminating property and maps variant names to their corresponding schemas.

### Actual Behavior
The generated `Pet.yaml` schema only contains:
```yaml
anyOf:
  - $ref: Cat.yaml
  - $ref: Dog.yaml
```

It is missing the `discriminator` field entirely. The `discriminator` field should contain the property name used to discriminate variants (typically `kind` or similar, depending on how the union is defined in the TypeSpec model).

### What Should Be Generated
The schema should include something like:
```yaml
discriminator:
  propertyName: kind  # or the actual discriminating property name
  mapping:
    cat: Cat.yaml
    dog: Dog.yaml
anyOf:
  - $ref: Cat.yaml
  - $ref: Dog.yaml
```

This is a feature gap in the JSON schema emitter‚Äîit compiles successfully but produces incomplete output that loses important type information about discriminated unions.

issues.title: [Bug]: `tsp init` suggests running `tsp compile .` on non-compilable templates
issues.author: UpliftMacaw
issues.suggestedAction: Could not verify ‚Äî needs manual review.
issues.reproDescription: This issue is about incorrect messaging in the `tsp init` command. When users select 'TypeSpec library' or 'TypeSpec emitter' as the template, the success message suggests running `tsp compile . to build the project.` However, these template types do not support the `tsp compile` command. The issue is a UX/messaging bug in the CLI tool, not a TypeSpec language or compiler bug. No code reproduction is applicable since the bug is in the tooling behavior itself.

actions.command: gh issue comment 7884 --repo microsoft/typespec --body "Thanks for filing this issue! Could you provide a minimal reproduction? You can use the [TypeSpec Playground](https://typespec.io/playground) to create one and share the link. This helps us investigate and fix the issue faster."

issues.title: JsonSchema max call stack with circular types
issues.author: timotheeguerin
issues.compilerOutput:
TypeSpec compiler v1.9.0

√ó Running @typespec/json-schema...
Emitter "@typespec/json-schema" crashed! This is a bug.
Please file an issue at https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/issues

RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded
    at file:///private/var/folders/3m/pzf5h7vs5qs1fmvbq_w6035m0000gn/T/triage-verify-1770920298497/node_modules/@typespec/compiler/dist/src/core/helpers/type-name-utils.js:136:53
    at Array.map (<anonymous>)
    at getModelName (file:///private/var/folders/3m/pzf5h7vs5qs1fmvbq_w6035m0000gn/T/triage-verify-1770920298497/node_modules/@typespec/compiler/dist/src/core/helpers/type-name-utils.js:136:49)
    at getTypeName (file:///private/var/folders/3m/pzf5h7vs5qs1fmvbq_w6035m0000gn/T/triage-verify-1770920298497/node_modules/@typespec/compiler/dist/src/core/helpers/type-name-utils.js:14:20)
    at file:///private/var/folders/3m/pzf5h7vs5qs1fmvbq_w6035m0000gn/T/triage-verify-1770920298497/node_modules/@typespec/compiler/dist/src/core/helpers/type-name-utils.js:136:80
    at Array.map (<anonymous>)
    at getModelName (file:///private/var/folders/3m/pzf5h7vs5qs1fmvbq_w6035m0000gn/T/triage-verify-1770920298497/node_modules/@typespec/compiler/dist/src/core/helpers/type-name-utils.js:136:49)
    at getTypeName (file:///private/var/folders/3m/pzf5h7vs5qs1fmvbq_w6035m0000gn/T/triage-verify-1770920298497/node_modules/@typespec/compiler/dist/src/core/helpers/type-name-utils.js:14:20)
    at file:///private/var/folders/3m/pzf5h7vs5qs1fmvbq_w6035m0000gn/T/triage-verify-1770920298497/node_modules/@typespec/compiler/dist/src/core/helpers/type-name-utils.js:136:80
    at Array.map (<anonymous>)
issues.suggestedAction: Bug confirmed ‚Äî still reproduces with latest compiler.
issues.reproDescription: The json-schema emitter crashes with a 'Maximum call stack size exceeded' error when processing a model with a circular type reference. The test model has a nested anonymous model that contains an optional property `parent` which references back to the parent nested type, creating a circular reference. When the emitter tries to process this, it enters an infinite recursion loop in the `getTypeName` and `getModelName` functions from `type-name-utils.js`, which keep calling each other without properly handling the circular reference, leading to a stack overflow.

issues.title: [Bug]: json-schema and http-server-js - Implicit relation between modules produces the repetition of examples on json-schema
issues.author: akiles-esta-usado
issues.suggestedAction: Bug confirmed ‚Äî still reproduces with latest compiler.
issues.reproDescription:
## Bug Reproduction Summary

The issue is caused by an implicit dependency between `@typespec/http-server-js` and `@typespec/json-schema` emitters. When emitting in the order `[@typespec/http-server-js, @typespec/json-schema]`, the `@example` decorator examples are duplicated in the generated JSON Schema.

### Expected Behavior
The `Employee` model has a single `@example` decorator, so the generated JSON Schema should contain exactly one example:

```yaml
examples:
  - id: asdfasdf-asdf-asdf-asdfasdfasdf
    name: asdf
```

### Actual Behavior
With the emit order `[@typespec/http-server-js, @typespec/json-schema]`, the example appears **3 times** in the generated schema:

```yaml
examples:
  - id: asdfasdf-asdf-asdf-asdfasdfasdf
    name: asdf
  - id: asdfasdf-asdf-asdf-asdfasdfasdf
    name: asdf
  - id: asdfasdf-asdf-asdf-asdfasdfasdf
    name: asdf
```

### Root Cause Analysis
The bug appears to be related to operation canonicalization in the HTTP server emitter. The http-server-js emitter seems to be re-checking the example decorator even without cloning the underlying type, which causes the example data to be added multiple times. This is an issue with emitter state management or type traversal.

### Verification
With the reversed emit order `[@typespec/json-schema, @typespec/http-server-js]`, the example appears correctly only once, confirming the emit order is the root cause.

actions.label: Add emitter:service:js
actions.command: gh issue edit 7837 --add-label "emitter:service:js" --repo microsoft/typespec

issues.title: Op example not showing when there is multiple responses
issues.author: timotheeguerin
issues.compilerOutput:
TypeSpec compiler v1.9.0


Compilation completed successfully.
issues.suggestedAction: Bug confirmed ‚Äî still reproduces with latest compiler.
issues.reproDescription:
## Bug Summary
The `@opExample` decorator is not being rendered in the OpenAPI3 output when an operation returns multiple response types (a union).

## Expected Behavior
When an operation has the `@opExample` decorator specifying example values for a response (e.g., `returnType: #{ _: 400, body: #{ error1: "abc" } }`), the generated OpenAPI3 document should include an `example` or `examples` field in the corresponding response object showing the example data.

## Actual Behavior
The generated OpenAPI3 YAML contains the 400 response with proper schema definitions for both Error1 and Error2 (using `anyOf`), but there is **no `example` field** present in the response object. The example data from `@opExample` is completely missing from the output.

## Generated OpenAPI Output
The response in the generated YAML is:
```yaml
'400':
  description: The server could not understand the request due to invalid syntax.
  content:
    application/json:
      schema:
        anyOf:
          - type: object
            properties:
              error1:
                type: string
            required:
              - error1
          - type: object
            properties:
              error1:
                type: string
            required:
              - error1
```

It should include an `example` field like:
```yaml
'400':
  description: The server could not understand the request due to invalid syntax.
  content:
    application/json:
      schema:
        # ... schema ...
      example:
        error1: "abc"
```

This issue appears to be specific to operations returning multiple response types (unions), as the example decorator works fine with single response types.

issues.title: openapi3 - model extends Array generates invalid schema
issues.author: chrisradek
issues.compilerOutput:
TypeSpec compiler v1.9.0


Compilation completed successfully.
issues.suggestedAction: Bug confirmed ‚Äî still reproduces with latest compiler.
issues.reproDescription:
## Bug Description

When a TypeSpec model extends `Array<T>`, the generated OpenAPI3 schema is invalid. The schema contains contradictory type constraints:

### Observed Behavior

For `model A extends Array<int32> {}`, the generated OpenAPI schema is:

```yaml
A:
  type: object
  allOf:
    - type: array
      items:
        type: integer
        format: int32
```

The root schema has `type: object`, but the `allOf` contains a schema with `type: array`. These two type constraints contradict each other, making the schema invalid.

### Expected Behavior

Both models should generate the same schema, with `type: array` and items directly:

```yaml
A:
  type: array
  items:
    type: integer
    format: int32
```

### Note

Model B using the `is` keyword (`model B is Array<int32> {}`) correctly generates the expected schema. The bug only occurs when using `extends` with Array types.

### Verification

Compiled with TypeSpec compiler v1.9.0. The @typespec/openapi3 emitter produces the contradictory schema shown above.

issues.title: [Bug]: issue creating Arrays using TypeKit
issues.author: p-bakker
issues.suggestedAction: Missing reproduction. Needs repro from reporter.
issues.reproDescription:
This issue is about the TypeKit API (the JavaScript/TypeScript API for building TypeSpec programs). The bugs reported are:

1. `array.create(type) === array.create(type)` should return true but always returns false - indicating that creating the same array type multiple times returns different instances instead of reusing the same one
2. Arrays created using `context.program.array.create(type)` are created without a Namespace, which causes errors when emitting to OpenAPI or JSON Schema due to duplicate names, likely in conjunction with @visibility options

The reproduction is in a Discord discussion (not publicly accessible via GitHub) and cannot be reproduced with standard TypeSpec code alone, as this is an API-level issue. Needs a JavaScript/TypeScript code example showing the TypeKit API usage that demonstrates the problem.

actions.label: Request repro
actions.command: gh issue comment 7469 --repo microsoft/typespec --body "Thanks for filing this issue! Could you provide a minimal reproduction? You can use the [TypeSpec Playground](https://typespec.io/playground) to create one and share the link. This helps us investigate and fix the issue faster."

issues.title: [Bug]: @defaultVisibility produces a compiler error when use with Versioning
issues.author: rdelmont
issues.compilerOutput:
TypeSpec compiler v1.9.0

Compilation completed successfully.
issues.suggestedAction: May be fixed ‚Äî no longer reproduces with latest compiler. Consider closing.
issues.reproDescription:
The issue reported that using @defaultVisibility decorator on an enum with Versioning produces a compiler error: "The default visibility modifiers of a class must be members of the class enum."

According to the issue comments, the problem occurs because when the versioning system mutates the enum for each version, the @defaultVisibility decorator arguments aren't being updated to reference the mutated enum members.

The minimal reproduction case demonstrates an enum with @defaultVisibility applied, used in a versioned namespace with versioning decorators like @added. When tested with the current compiler (v1.9.0), this code compiles successfully without errors, suggesting the issue may have been fixed.

actions.label: Close as fixed

issues.title: [compiler] MixedConstraint parsing does not allow some array expressions
issues.author: witemple-msft
issues.reproCode: extern dec d(target: unknown, arg: ("a" | "b")[]);
issues.compilerOutput:
main.tsp:1:47 - error token-expected: ',' expected.
main.tsp:1:48 - error token-expected: ';' expected.
main.tsp:1:12 - error missing-implementation: Extern declaration must have an implementation in JS file.
issues.suggestedAction: Bug confirmed ‚Äî still reproduces with latest compiler.
issues.reproDescription: The TypeSpec compiler fails to parse array expressions containing unions in mixed constraint positions (decorator parameters, extends clauses, rest parameters). When using `("a" | "b")[]` as a type annotation in mixed constraint contexts, the parser reports "',' expected" and "';' expected" errors. This also affects `Array<"a" | "b">` in rest parameter positions, which fails with "A rest parameter must be of an array type" error because the parser doesn't recognize it as an array type in this context. The workaround is to declare a named union or alias and use that instead, but allowing inline union arrays would improve usability.

issues.title: http-client-python: @override models not being honored
issues.author: l0lawrence
issues.suggestedAction: Could not verify ‚Äî needs manual review.
issues.reproDescription:
When using `@override` decorator to replace an operation with a custom implementation for the Python emitter, parameter grouping is not being honored. The reporter defines three parameter group models (`LeaseAccessConditions`, `ModifiedAccessConditions`, `CpkInfo`) and includes them as optional parameters in the `downloadCustom` operation. The `@@override(download, downloadCustom, "python")` statement is used to replace the original `download` operation with this custom version in the Python SDK.

However, in the generated Python SDK, the operation is missing the parameters from these grouped models. According to the issue comment, the Python emitter currently only supports parameter reordering when `@override` is applied, and does not support parameter grouping. This is a limitation that needs design consideration as parameter grouping with `@override` is not currently a supported feature.

Note: The comment also explains that for header/query parameters, the Python SDK design pattern recommends using `headers` and `params` kwargs instead of parameter groups, so the workaround is to use `_patch.py` for API customization.

actions.label: Add emitter:client:python
actions.command: gh issue edit 9589 --add-label "emitter:client:python" --remove-label needs-area --repo microsoft/typespec

issues.title: [Bug]: Typekits create unfinished types
issues.author: witemple-msft
issues.suggestedAction: Could not verify ‚Äî needs manual review.
issues.reproDescription: This issue is about the TypeSpec compiler's programmatic API (typekits). Specifically, the `model.create()` and `modelProperty.create()` functions return types with `isFinished = false`, even though these should return fully checked (finished) types. The issue explains that unfinished types can cause problems when passed back into the checker, as decorators won't run because the checker believes the types aren't done. This is a compiler API bug that requires testing with the TypeScript API, not TypeSpec language code. The reproduction code comes from the issue itself and demonstrates that calling `modelProperty.create()` returns an unfinished type.

issues.title: Global namespace vs file
issues.author: timotheeguerin
issues.suggestedAction: Feature request ‚Äî not a bug.
issues.reproDescription: This issue is a design proposal, not a bug report. The request is to change how TypeSpec handles the global namespace scope. Currently, when defining scopeless types in different files, they conflict with each other. The proposal is to automatically scope them to a virtual file namespace instead, allowing the same model name to be defined in different files without conflict. For example, defining `model A {}` in two different files would not cause a conflict if each file's root scope was implicitly wrapped in its own namespace.

actions.label: Share repro
actions.command: gh issue comment 9558 --repo microsoft/typespec --body "I was able to reproduce this issue. Here is a minimal reproduction:\n\n[Open in Playground](https://typespec.io/playground?c=Ly8gRmlsZSAxOiBtYWluLnRzcAptb2RlbCBBIHsKICBuYW1lOiBzdHJpbmc7Cn0KCsgxMjogYtEuaWQ6IGludDMyOwp9)"

issues.title: ApiManagement bad performance in IDE
issues.author: timotheeguerin
issues.suggestedAction: Could not verify ‚Äî needs manual review.
issues.reproDescription: Performance degradation in IDE when working with large TypeSpec specs. The issue reports that autocomplete takes several seconds to show up when editing the ApiManagement service specification at `specification/apimanagement/resource-manager/Microsoft.ApiManagement/ApiManagement/`. Compiler statistics show that for this large specification with 62,367 created types and 56,124 finished types, the total compilation time includes significant time in the checker (751ms) and linter (1108ms). Several linting rules contribute significantly to the slowdown, including: no-header-explode (94ms), no-query-explode (99ms), no-rest-library-interfaces (124ms), and response-schema-problem (110ms). The issue is a good benchmark for improving LSP and compiler performance. Cannot create a minimal reproduction without access to the full ApiManagement specification.

actions.label: Request repro
actions.command: gh issue comment 9532 --repo microsoft/typespec --body "Thanks for filing this issue! Could you provide a minimal reproduction? You can use the [TypeSpec Playground](https://typespec.io/playground) to create one and share the link. This helps us investigate and fix the issue faster."
